articles.headline: In Saudi Arabia’s War in Yemen, No Refuge on Land or Sea
articles.snippet: Outrage over civilian deaths in Yemen has focused on airstrikes. But at sea, the Saudi-led coalition is suspected of attacking many fishing boats, killing dozens of people.
articles.abstract: Outrage over civilian deaths in Yemen has focused on airstrikes. But at sea, the Saudi-led coalition is suspected of attacking many fishing boats, killing dozens of people.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHOKHA, Yemen — The first sign of trouble was the helicopter that hovered over the small Yemeni fishing trawler as it cut across the Red Sea. Then a warship appeared, its guns pointed at the boat.

articles.headline: Social Media’s Forever War
articles.snippet: New Senate reports show that the Russian influence campaign for the 2016 election ushered in a new era of extended conflict.
articles.abstract: New Senate reports show that the Russian influence campaign for the 2016 election ushered in a new era of extended conflict.
articles.lead_paragraph: A year ago, in his annual New Year’s resolution post, Mark Zuckerberg pledged to spend 2018 fixing Facebook by addressing foreign manipulation, election interference and other threats. He and other tech leaders should probably renew that vow for 2019, and 2020, and possibly every year after that.

articles.headline: Trump Officials Plan to Rescind Obama-Era School Discipline Policies
articles.snippet: A school safety commission created after the Parkland school massacre contends that the policies, intended to protect minority children, eased up too much on discipline.
articles.abstract: A school safety commission created after the Parkland school massacre contends that the policies, intended to protect minority children, eased up too much on discipline.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration is planning to roll back Obama-era policies aimed at ensuring that minority children are not unfairly disciplined, arguing that the efforts have eased up on punishment and contributed to rising violence in the nation’s schools, according to documents obtained by The New York Times.
articles.byline: By Erica L. Green and Katie Benner

articles.headline: CBS Says Les Moonves Will Not Receive $120 Million Severance
articles.snippet: The company announced that Mr. Moonves, who was forced out in September after multiple allegations of sexual misconduct, had breached his employment contract.
articles.abstract: The company announced that Mr. Moonves, who was forced out in September after multiple allegations of sexual misconduct, had breached his employment contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: The CBS Corporation, battered by scandal and facing a leadership vacuum, said its former chief executive, Leslie Moonves, misled the company about multiple allegations of sexual misconduct and tried to hide evidence as he made a frenzied attempt to save his legacy and reap a lucrative severance. As a result, the company said Mr. Moonves would not receive his $120 million exit payout.
articles.byline: By Edmund Lee and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: 1MDB Case in Malaysia Deepens Goldman’s Crisis
articles.snippet: The Malaysian government filed charges against Goldman Sachs for its role in the 1MDB fraud, and in the United States, the bank’s lawyers held talks with federal prosecutors.
articles.abstract: The Malaysian government filed charges against Goldman Sachs for its role in the 1MDB fraud, and in the United States, the bank’s lawyers held talks with federal prosecutors.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since becoming a symbol of Wall Street greed during the financial crisis, Goldman Sachs has tried to recast its image as an investment bank that cares as much about ethics as it does its bottom line.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Alexandra Stevenson

articles.headline: Facebook, Twitter and YouTube Withheld Russia Data, Reports Say
articles.snippet: Reports to the Senate on Russian interference in the 2016 election and beyond criticized the tech companies for failing to disclose important details.
articles.abstract: Reports to the Senate on Russian interference in the 2016 election and beyond criticized the tech companies for failing to disclose important details.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When lawmakers asked YouTube, a unit of Google, to provide information about Russian manipulation efforts, it did not disclose how many people watched the videos on its site that were created by Russian trolls.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel, Daisuke Wakabayashi and Kate Conger

articles.headline: A Toaster on Wheels to Deliver Groceries? Self-Driving Tech Tests Practical Uses
articles.snippet: With driverless passenger services slow to become realities, the autonomous industry is casting about for ways to profitably use its technology.
articles.abstract: With driverless passenger services slow to become realities, the autonomous industry is casting about for ways to profitably use its technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz. — Last Thursday morning in the desert town of Scottsdale, Ariz., a tiny robotic car turned onto a neighborhood street and pulled up to a home with a Spanish-tiled roof and synthetic grass in the front yard.

articles.headline: ‘Not Hiding My Disgust’: Judge Rebukes Flynn, Then Delays Sentencing
articles.snippet: A federal judge transformed a seemingly straightforward sentencing hearing for Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, into a dramatic showdown.
articles.abstract: A federal judge transformed a seemingly straightforward sentencing hearing for Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, into a dramatic showdown.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge transformed a seemingly straightforward sentencing hearing for Michael T. Flynn, President Trump’s first national security adviser, into a dramatic showdown on Tuesday, expressing “disgust” at Mr. Flynn’s efforts to mislead federal investigators and dismissing suggestions he had been treated unfairly.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Russian Trolls Came for Instagram, Too
articles.snippet: A look at posts from the Internet Research Agency reveals that the group used Instagram for several distinct purposes.
articles.abstract: A look at posts from the Internet Research Agency reveals that the group used Instagram for several distinct purposes.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the wake of the 2016 election, Instagram — known as the home of preening influencers, artfully arranged grain bowls and Icelandic vacation photos — somehow escaped much of the scrutiny of other social networks.

articles.headline: Huawei’s ‘Wolf Culture’ Helped It Grow, and Got It Into Trouble
articles.snippet: The Chinese tech giant cultivated a hard-charging spirit in its quest for world dominance. Some employees may have been pushed too far.
articles.abstract: The Chinese tech giant cultivated a hard-charging spirit in its quest for world dominance. Some employees may have been pushed too far.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — Earthquakes, terrorist attacks and low oxygen levels on Mount Everest could not hold them back.
